metadata.titleEn: 1-km daily average air temperature of the Tibetan Plateau (1980-2014)
metadata.description:
1) Data content (including elements and meanings): Gridded daily average air temperature of the Tibetan Plateau during 1980-2014 at 1-km resolution

2) Data source and processing method: Developed by integrating 8 types of reanalysis data (i.e., NNRP-2, 20CRV2c, JRA-55, ERA-Interim, MERRA2, CFSR, GLDAS and ERA5) downscaled with MODIS-estimated temperature lapse rates based on machine learing 

3) Data quality description: According to leave-one-out validation based on stations, the average RMSE at China Adimistration Stations is about 1.7 ℃ and that at high-elevation field stations is about 1.9 ℃
metadata.instructions: In geotiff format which can be read directly by mutiple GIS softwares (such as ArcGIS and QGIS)

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) and its surrounding region are considered as the Third Pole on the Earth with an average elevation of approximately 4000 m. Due to the high elevation, TP has a warming rate higher than the global average, resulting in various severe environmental changes such as glacier retreat, permafrost degradation, lake expansion, and increasing river discharge and sediment flux. Air temperature is the most direct indicator of global warming, and it is also an important variable for investigating the changes and mechanisms of various hydrological and ecological processes such as snow or glacier melting and photosynthesis. However, air temperature observations are scarce in TP in particular in high-altitude areas due to harsh terrain and weather conditions. To overcome the problem of air temperature data scarcity, a variety of reanalysis and land data assimilation methods have been developed in the last several decades, such as the NCEP/DOE Reanalysis 2 Project (NNRP-2), the 20th Century Reanalysis Version V2c (20CRV2c), the Japanese 55-year Reanalysis Project (JRA-55), the ERA-Interim, the Modern-Era Retrospective analysis for Research and Applications Version 2 (MERRA-2), the NCEP Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR), the Global Land Data Assimilation System Version 2 (GLDAS-2) and ERA5. These efforts have produced various datasets by using advanced model and assimilation techniques to efficiently incorporate observations from multiple sources with consideration of physical relations between multiple types of the observations. The air temperature datasets derived from the reanalysis or assimilation data need to be corrected for complex terrains in TP, because spatial resolutions (ranging from 0.25° to 2.5°) of the derived data are too coarse to reflect complex topography in TP. Downscaling is thus needed to achieve a higher horizontal resolution, and the resolution of 1 – 3 km is considered to be satisfactory for complex terrains. For downscaling air temperature, the temperature lapse rate (TLR) (i.e., the rate of temperature change with elevation) is the most commonly used variable. A constant value of 0.0065 °C/m has been used for downscaling and distributing the air temperature data of CFSR, GLDAS and JRA-55 from a coarse grid to a finer grid. However, since TLR is not a constant, but varies in space and time in TP and its surrounding areas, using a constant TLR is unsuitable for downscaling the reanalysis data in TP such as ERA-Interim. Methods that estimate more accurate TLRs have been developed, for instance, by calculating local and monthly TLRs based on neighboring stations or using the temperature gradient of synoptic data from different pressure levels. It has been shown that the station-based TLR may not be optimal for downscaling when a small number of weather stations are insufficient to represent spatial variability at the scale of a grid block. Recently, based on the strong correlation and consistency between air temperature and remote sensing land surface temperature (LST), MODIS LST data have been used for estimating TLR for the TP.
research objective: To resolve the issue that Tair observations are scarce in the TP western part and at high elevation, many studies have estimated daily air temperatures by using MODIS land surface temperature (LST) and various reanalysis datasets. To improve the Tair estimation, this study develops a novel machine-learning based method that uses the Gradient Boosting model to efficiently integrate observations from high-elevation stations with eight widely used air temperature reanalysis and assimilation datasets (i.e., NNRP-2, 20CRV2c, JRA-55, ERA-Interim, MERRA-2, CFSR, ERA5 and GLDAS2) downscaled with remote sensing-based temperature lapse rates (TLR). This method is used to generate a new dataset of daily air temperature with the 1-km resolution for the period of 1980 – 2014. This study also provides a framework for integrating multiple reanalysis and assimilation temperature data with elevation correction in mountainous regions that is not restricted to the TP.
challenges: The existing methods however have not adequately addressed the problems of missing data (mainly caused by clouds) and unreliable estimates of TLR.
methods: This study develops a novel machine-learning based method that uses the Gradient Boosting model to efficiently integrate observations from high-elevation stations with eight widely used air temperature reanalysis and assimilation datasets (i.e., NNRP-2, 20CRV2c, JRA-55, ERA-Interim, MERRA-2, CFSR, ERA5 and GLDAS2) downscaled with remote sensing-based temperature lapse rates (TLR). A new TLR estimation method is developed to first estimate spatially continuous monthly TLRs from MODIS LST and then downscale daily mean Tair from eight reanalysis and assimilation datasets to obtain Tair at the 1-km resolution using the MODIS-estimated TLRs. The Gradient Boosting (GB) model is selected for integrating the eight downscaled Tair and five other auxiliary variables. The models are trained and validated using observations from 100 common stations (i.e. China Meteorology Administration stations) and 13 independent high-elevation stations (4 on glaciers).
dataset: The models are trained and validated using observations from 100 common stations (i.e. China Meteorology Administration stations) and 13 independent high-elevation stations (4 on glaciers).
findings: The results show that the proposed TLR estimation method can efficiently reduce exceptional TLRs in the meantime keeping acceptable downscaling accuracy. The downscaled Tair from JRA-55 is the best among the eight downscaled datasets followed by ERA-Interim, MERRA-2, CFSR and others. Finally, the GB-integrated Tair further outperforms the downscaled JRA-55 Tair with the mean root-mean-squared-deviation (RMSD) of 1.7 °C versus 2.0 °C, especially in high-elevation stations with mean RMSD of 1.9 °C versus 2.7 °C. Both the MODIS-estimated TLR and the high-elevation training observations are demonstrated to significantly improve the air temperature estimation accuracy of the GB model in high-elevation stations.

background: The air temperature lapse rate (TLR) is a key parameter for interpolating air temperature data in high mountainous regions such as the Tibetan Plateau (TP). The Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) land surface temperature (LST) has been frequently used for estimating air temperature during the past decade, but its performance in estimating the TLR in the TP has seldom been investigated.
research objective: This study employed two methods in estimating the TLR based on MODIS LSTs compared with the “observed” TLR derived from 86 stations across the TP.
challenges: The problem of sparse air temperature data is more severe in the western TP. The accurate estimation of the TLR largely relies on sufficiently dense and representative observations. However, the sparse distribution of stations in the TP, especially in high-altitude regions, may lead to a large bias.
methods: The two methods include a method for directly computing the lapse rate from MODIS LST (DFM) and a second method for calculating the lapse rate of estimated air temperatures based on air temperature estimation from MODIS LST (TEM).
dataset: Daily observations of Tmax, Tmin, Tmean, precipitation, sunshine duration, vapor pressure, wind speed, and relative humidity of 8 years (2003–2010) from 86 available CMA stations were used. Daily LST data at 1-km resolution from the data sets of “MODIS/Terra Land Surface Temperature and Emissivity Daily L3 Global 1 km Grid SIN V006” (MOD11A1) and “MODIS/Aqua Land Surface Temperature and Emissivity Daily L3 Global 1 km Grid SIN V006” (MYD11A1) were used.
findings: The MODIS LST-estimated TLR for Tmean is more accurate than that of Tmin and Tmax. The spatial and seasonal patterns of MODIS LST-estimated TLRs of Tmean from both DFM and TEM are found to be highly consistent with the observed TLRs.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how machine learning techniques are used to integrate multiple reanalysis datasets for air temperature estimation in high-altitude regions?
Example.Answer: A machine-learning based method using the Gradient Boosting model integrates observations from high-elevation stations with eight widely used air temperature reanalysis and assimilation datasets, downscaled with remote sensing-based temperature lapse rates, to estimate daily air temperature at 1-km resolution.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in estimating temperature lapse rates (TLR) in high mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the sparse distribution of stations in high-altitude regions of the Tibetan Plateau, which can lead to large biases in the estimation of temperature lapse rates due to insufficiently dense and representative observations.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of datasets used to validate air temperature estimation methods in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: The models are trained and validated using observations from 100 common stations from the China Meteorology Administration and 13 independent high-elevation stations, including 4 on glaciers, to ensure accurate air temperature estimation in the Tibetan Plateau.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the distinguishing features of the machine-learning based method employed for air temperature estimation in the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: Gradient Boosting model, integrates observations from high-elevation stations with eight reanalysis datasets, downscales data using MODIS-estimated temperature lapse rates, incorporates high-elevation training observations, uses spatially continuous TLRs derived from MODIS LST.

Feature Specification.Question: What factors influence the accuracy of temperature lapse rate (TLR) estimation methods in high mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: density and representativeness of observational data, sparse station distribution, use of MODIS LST data, spatial and seasonal consistency with observed TLRs

Definition.Question: What does 'temperature lapse rate' mean in the context of air temperature downscaling in high-elevation regions?
Definition.Answer: In the context of air temperature downscaling, 'temperature lapse rate' (TLR) refers to the rate of temperature change with elevation. It is a crucial parameter for interpolating air temperature data in mountainous regions, and accurate estimation of TLR is important for downscaling reanalysis data to higher resolutions.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of MODIS LST for estimating temperature lapse rates compare to more traditional station-based methods in terms of accuracy and spatial representation?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS LST-based methods provide a more spatially continuous estimation of temperature lapse rates (TLR), which is particularly useful in regions like the Tibetan Plateau where station data is sparse. The MODIS LST-estimated TLR for mean air temperature is found to be more accurate than for minimum and maximum temperatures, and shows high consistency with observed TLRs. Traditional station-based methods may not adequately capture spatial variability due to the limited number of stations, especially in high-altitude regions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using machine learning models versus traditional reanalysis data for air temperature estimation in the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning models, such as the Gradient Boosting model, offer a way to integrate multiple datasets and address missing data issues, but they also face challenges related to training data availability, especially in high-altitude regions. Traditional reanalysis data methods can suffer from coarse spatial resolution and may not accurately reflect complex terrains without downscaling. Both approaches aim to improve accuracy but have distinct challenges related to data integration and handling of sparse observational data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the scarcity of air temperature observations in the Tibetan Plateau, especially in high-altitude areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity of air temperature observations in the Tibetan Plateau, particularly in high-altitude areas, is caused by harsh terrain and weather conditions that make it challenging to establish and maintain observation stations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is downscaling necessary for air temperature datasets derived from reanalysis or assimilation data in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Downscaling is necessary because the spatial resolutions of derived reanalysis or assimilation data are too coarse to reflect the complex topography of the Tibetan Plateau, requiring a finer resolution to accurately represent the temperature variations across its diverse terrain.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for the inadequacy of existing methods in addressing missing data and unreliable temperature lapse rate estimates when estimating air temperature in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Existing methods have not adequately addressed missing data, mainly caused by cloud cover, and unreliable estimates of temperature lapse rates because traditional approaches often rely on insufficiently dense and representative observations, leading to potential biases and inaccuracies in high-altitude regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the consequences of integrating machine learning methods with reanalysis data for estimating air temperatures in high-altitude regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating machine learning methods with reanalysis data can significantly improve the estimation accuracy of air temperatures in high-altitude regions, such as the Tibetan Plateau, by efficiently addressing issues like missing data and unreliable temperature lapse rates. This results in more accurate downscaled air temperature datasets, which are crucial for climate analysis and hydrological modeling.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of developing new methods for estimating temperature lapse rates based on remote sensing data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Developing new methods for estimating temperature lapse rates based on remote sensing data can lead to more accurate air temperature datasets, especially in regions with complex terrains and sparse observational data. This can improve the integration of various reanalysis datasets and enhance the accuracy of climate and hydrological models, particularly in high-elevation regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind integrating multiple reanalysis datasets with machine learning techniques for estimating air temperature in high-elevation regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to overcome the scarcity of air temperature observations in the Tibetan Plateau, especially in high-altitude areas, by efficiently integrating observations from high-elevation stations with widely used reanalysis and assimilation datasets. This approach aims to improve the estimation of air temperature by incorporating elevation correction methods that are not limited to the Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop new methods for estimating temperature lapse rates in mountainous regions using remote sensing data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing new methods for estimating temperature lapse rates is crucial because existing methods have not adequately addressed issues such as missing data caused by clouds and unreliable lapse rate estimates. Accurate lapse rate estimation is essential for downscaling reanalysis data to reflect the complex topography of regions like the Tibetan Plateau, where traditional constant lapse rates may not be suitable.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the use of MODIS land surface temperature data for calculating temperature lapse rates in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The motivation for using MODIS land surface temperature data lies in its strong correlation with air temperature, which makes it a valuable proxy for estimating temperature lapse rates. This approach helps address the challenges posed by the sparse distribution of temperature observation stations in the Tibetan Plateau, especially in high-altitude regions, aiding in the creation of more accurate and spatially continuous temperature datasets.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in integrating various reanalysis datasets with remote sensing-based temperature lapse rates to develop a high-resolution air temperature dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve using a machine-learning based method, specifically the Gradient Boosting model, to efficiently integrate observations from high-elevation stations with eight widely used air temperature reanalysis and assimilation datasets. These datasets are then downscaled using remote sensing-based temperature lapse rates estimated from MODIS LST. This process includes estimating spatially continuous monthly TLRs and using them to downscale daily mean air temperatures from the reanalysis and assimilation datasets to a 1-km resolution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can machine learning techniques be employed to address the challenges of missing data and unreliable temperature lapse rate estimates in air temperature datasets for complex terrains?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Machine learning techniques, such as the Gradient Boosting model, can be employed to integrate multiple sources of data, including observations from high-elevation stations and various reanalysis datasets. By utilizing these models, researchers can improve the estimation of air temperature by reducing the impact of missing data and refining temperature lapse rate estimates. This approach leverages the strong correlation between air temperature and remote sensing land surface temperature (LST) to estimate more accurate TLRs and integrate them into the dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be used to accurately estimate temperature lapse rates in the Tibetan Plateau, considering the sparse distribution of weather stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Two methods can be employed to accurately estimate temperature lapse rates in the Tibetan Plateau: one involves directly computing the lapse rate from MODIS LST, and the other calculates the lapse rate based on estimated air temperatures derived from MODIS LST. These methods are compared with 'observed' TLR derived from station data to ensure accuracy. The use of MODIS LST allows for a more spatially continuous estimation of TLR, which is critical given the sparse distribution of weather stations in high-altitude regions.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the integration of multiple reanalysis datasets with high-elevation observations for generating high-resolution air temperature datasets?
Enablement.Answer: A machine-learning based method using the Gradient Boosting model efficiently integrates observations from high-elevation stations with eight widely used air temperature reanalysis and assimilation datasets, downscaled with remote sensing-based temperature lapse rates (TLR).

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in remote sensing technologies facilitate the estimation of air temperature lapse rates in complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: MODIS land surface temperature (LST) data are used to estimate spatially continuous temperature lapse rates (TLR), which are crucial for downscaling and distributing air temperature data across the complex terrains of the Tibetan Plateau.

Enablement.Question: What data sources and conditions are necessary to address the challenges of sparse air temperature observations in high-altitude regions?
Enablement.Answer: To address the sparse distribution of air temperature observations, integrating data from multiple reanalysis datasets and MODIS LST-based temperature lapse rates, along with observations from both common and high-elevation field stations, is essential.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multiple reanalysis datasets and machine learning methods lead to improved accuracy in air temperature estimation for the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of multiple reanalysis datasets and machine learning methods can improve accuracy by efficiently combining observations from high-elevation stations with various datasets, allowing for a comprehensive analysis that accounts for the spatial and temporal variability of temperature lapse rates. This approach leverages the strengths of each dataset, providing a more robust air temperature estimation, especially in complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise from the sparse distribution of observation stations in high-altitude regions when estimating air temperature lapse rates?
Expectation.Answer: The sparse distribution of observation stations in high-altitude regions can lead to challenges such as large biases in the estimation of air temperature lapse rates due to insufficient data density and representativeness. This scarcity of data may hinder the accurate interpolation of air temperature, affecting the reliability of temperature estimates in these regions.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges and drawbacks of relying on MODIS land surface temperature (LST) data for estimating temperature lapse rates (TLR) in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: One potential challenge of relying on MODIS LST data for estimating TLR in mountainous regions is the issue of data sparsity, particularly in high-altitude areas where the distribution of stations is sparse. This can lead to large biases in TLR estimation. Additionally, the presence of clouds can cause missing data in the MODIS LST records, making it difficult to obtain reliable TLR estimates. Despite these challenges, using MODIS LST has been shown to yield more accurate TLR estimates compared to constant or station-based TLRs.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when estimating temperature lapse rates in the Tibetan Plateau using remote sensing data.
Assertion.Answer: Estimating temperature lapse rates (TLR) in the Tibetan Plateau using remote sensing data faces challenges such as the sparse distribution of weather stations, particularly in high-altitude regions, which can lead to large biases. Additionally, the estimation of TLR largely relies on sufficiently dense and representative observations, which are often lacking in this region.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how machine learning methods are employed to address the issue of missing data in air temperature datasets for the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Machine learning methods, like the Gradient Boosting model, are employed to integrate various reanalysis datasets and auxiliary variables to generate a more complete and accurate air temperature dataset. These methods can help address missing data issues, particularly those caused by cloud cover, by leveraging patterns in the available data and incorporating elevation corrections for mountainous regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and describe the machine-learning techniques used for integrating multiple reanalysis datasets to improve air temperature estimation accuracy in high-elevation regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A machine-learning based method using the Gradient Boosting model was developed to integrate observations from high-elevation stations with eight widely used air temperature reanalysis and assimilation datasets. This method involves downscaling with remote sensing-based temperature lapse rates to generate a dataset of daily air temperature at 1-km resolution. The Gradient Boosting model efficiently integrates the downscaled data with auxiliary variables, significantly improving air temperature estimation accuracy, especially in high-elevation stations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate and summarize how MODIS land surface temperature data has been utilized to estimate air temperature lapse rates and its effectiveness in the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: MODIS land surface temperature (LST) data has been used to estimate air temperature lapse rates by developing methods to compute lapse rates directly from LST or by estimating air temperatures from LST data. The MODIS LST-estimated lapse rates for mean temperature have shown higher accuracy than those for minimum and maximum temperatures. The spatial and seasonal patterns of MODIS LST-estimated lapse rates are highly consistent with observed lapse rates, indicating the effectiveness of using MODIS LST data in estimating air temperature lapse rates in the Tibetan Plateau.
